Graphical abstract The intrinsic catalytic activity, different molecular strategies, and thoughtful understanding of transition metal-based single-atom catalysts (TM-SACs) for CO2 reduction along with the current challenges and future research directions are recapitulated in this review. The continuous increase of global atmospheric CO2 concentrations brutally damages our environment. A series of methods have been developed to convert CO2 to valuable fuels and value-added chemicals to maintain the equilibrium of carbon cycles. The electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is one of the promising methods to produce fuels and chemicals, and it could offer sustainable paths to decrease carbon intensity and support renewable energy. Thus, significant research efforts and highly efficient catalysts are essential for converting CO2 into other valuable chemicals and fuels. Transition metal-based single atoms catalysts (TM-SACs) have recently received much attention and offer outstanding electrochemical applications with high activity and selectivity opportunities. By taking advantage of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, TM-SACs are the new rising star for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to the value-added product with high selectivity. In recent years, enormous research effort has been made to synthesize different TM-SACs with different M–N x sites and study the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO. This review has discussed the development and characterization of different TM-SACs with various catalytic sites, fundamental understanding of the electrochemical process in CO2RR, intrinsic catalytic activity, and molecular strategics of SACs responsible for CO2RR. Furthermore, we extensively review previous studies on 1st-row transition metals TM-SACs (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Zn, Sn) and dual-atom catalysts (DACs) utilized for electrochemical CO2 conversions and highlight the opportunities and challenges. Keywords CO2RR Single-atom catalyst SACs Dual-atom catalyst DACs Transition metals Support catalysts 1 Introduction In the 21st century, the important concern is protecting energy and the environment. Since the second industrial revolution, fossil fuels-based energy sources such as coal, petroleum, and natural gas, have been considered major energy carriers to fulfill our energy requirement [1]. The rapid demand for industrialization, urbanization, and fast growth of populations increase the energy requirements continuously. Fossil fuel consumption is continuously increased due to the dearth of renewable energy sources, and excessive use causes serious energy crises and environmental problems [2–7]. The huge ingesting of fossil fuels dramatically increases the atmosphere's carbon dioxide (CO2) level [8]. By March 2020, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere was 414.11 parts per million (ppm), which is quite higher than the safety limit (350 ppm) [9]. Different processes have been adapted to decrease the atmospheric CO2 level, including (1) capture and storage, (2) adoption of renewable energy resources against fossil fuels, and (3) conversion of CO2 to valuable products. The demerit of the processes is high energy intakes, unsustainability, uncertainty in the storage, and concerns over escape [10,11]. The electrochemical conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuels is the best method to reduce atmospheric CO2 and maintain carbon cycles [12,13]. The electrochemical CO2 conversion is challenging due to its high bond energy (CO, 806 kJ mol−1). The linear structure makes it relatively stable and unreactive; it involves a multi-electron transfer process with a higher free energy barrier [12,14–17]. So highly advanced technologies and significant research efforts are required for converting CO2 into other valuable chemicals and fuels. The CO2 conversion is achieved by the different processes such as thermal hydrogenations, biological, photochemical, photoelectrochemical, and electrochemical methods [18–23]. In the last couple of years, the electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) has been extensively studied and quite promising over other processes. The advantage of electrochemical CO2RR can be expressed as (1) the reaction can take place in ambient conditions, (2) the reduction process can be controlled by varying the applied potential, (3) the process can be easily scaled up, (4) the process is compact and easily modulated [24–26]. Though significant progress has been achieved in CO2RR, it still suffers some lag behind. That is due to the sluggish kinetics and high overpotential requirements to overcome high energy barriers for intermediate formations, limited mass transfer capacity, and multistep electron transfer process. CO2RR is competing with hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in an aqueous solution, which results in suffering in efficiency and selectivity [27–33]. Therefore, highly efficient and stable catalysts are required to reduce CO2 at lower overpotentials and higher current density. For electrochemical CO2RR, the precious noble metal catalysts such as Ag, Au, Pd, and its alloy have been considered benchmark catalysts for reducing CO2 to CO because they weakly bind with the *CO species can tightly bind with *COOH intermediates [34–36]. However, the cost factor and scarceness limit the prevalent applications. The monodispersed supported metal catalysts have become the frontier research and development in both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis [37–40]. In the case of single-atom catalysts (SACs), every single atom is exposed to a lower coordination number. It acts as an electrocatalytic active centre with 100% utilization of the atomic efficiency of the metals. The SACs have enhanced unsaturated bonds and atomic size and broadened the Kubo gap. In nature, the Mg-porphyrin complex present in chlorophyll has SACs like structure and plays a significant role in the photosynthesis process. Fe-porphyrins complex in cytochrome also have SACs like structure and play a significant role in transferring CO2 [41–43]. The physicochemical and catalytic properties are changed significantly with the decrease in particle size of the materials to a single-atom level [44]. For example, Pt nanoparticles' efficiency increases from 9.5% to 26%, decreasing the size from 11.7 to 3.9 nm, respectively [45]. Since lowering the atomic size decreases the stability and increases the free energy, thus to stabilize the single-atom needs to have bonds or anchoring with other solid supports catalysts. The solid support acts as a ligand to coordinate and stabilize the single metal atoms. The heteroatom present in the support modifies the charge density with the asymmetrical spin state [46–48]. Each isolated metal atom is territorially separated from the other and has an identical coordination environment. Due to the unique features, SACs have quite a different properties than nano and bulk counterparts [49–53]. There are significant challenges to fabricating the SACs, i.e., increasing the metal loading above 1%, uniform distributions of single atoms on the reliable support, and controlling the coordination environment around the single atom. Thus, support materials with high surface and strong coordination sites are vital to increasing the loading percentage and uniform distributions. The coordination linkage of SACs varied with different support materials such as oxides, hydroxides, nano carbons, and dichalcogenides. The SACs have been applied on various applications such as catalytic, bio-medical, photochemical, and electrochemical [37,50,54–56]. Since the exploration of SACs, the increase in research reports based on SACs has been skyrocketing. In particular, the exploration of different SACs towards CO2RR has been profusely documented. For noble metal-based SACs, different CO2RR products such as CO, HCOOH, CH4, and CH2O, are formed, and most of them are studied only by quantum chemistry calculations [34,57]. Now, the transition metal-based single-atom catalysts (TM-SACs) are the rising star for converting CO2 to valuable products also used for other electrochemical applications (Fig. 1 a and b). Though reviews have been documented on SACs for various applications, very few compilations of research efforts on transition metal-based single-atom catalysts (TM-SACs) highlight the synthesis process characterization techniques and application towards CO2RR is documented yet [58–72]. In this report, we have thoroughly discussed the recent progress of TM-SACs towards electrocatalytic CO2RR with a summarizing note on the synthesis process, essential principles to guide the formation of SACs, and the techniques used to characterize the SACs. The fundamental reaction mechanism and different catalytic sites involved in electrochemical CO2RR are highlighted. Finally, the challenges and outlooks for future research scope are presented. 2 Insights on the electrochemistry of CO2RR The electrochemical CO2RR is a complex multi-step electron transfer reaction compared to hydrogen and oxygen evolutions reaction, and it follows the two to twelve-electron reaction pathways. As a result, numerous products are formed. The final product of the reaction depends on the types of catalysts [9,73–75]. The heterogeneous catalysis process for CO2RR mainly follows the four-step reaction paths. In the first step, the CO2 molecule (from the CO2 saturated electrolyte) is chemically adsorbed on the electrocatalysts' surface. In the second step, the bond cleavage (C–O) and bond-forming (C–H) occur through the electron and proton transfer process. This step is the slowest or rate-determining step in CO2RR because high energy (806 kJ mol−1) must break the CO bond and form the CO2 – intermediate. In the third step, the reduction products are formed, and in the fourth step, the products are removed from the catalyst surfaces [9]. The reaction's outcome depends on the type of electrocatalysts, electrolytes, and the applied electrode potentials. The final reaction products of the CO2RR are of different oxidations states of carbon compounds such as carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), oxalic acid (C2H2O4), methyl alcohol (CH3OH), ethyl alcohol (C2H5OH), propyl alcohol (C3H7OH), methane (CH4), and ethane (C2H4). Fig. 2 exhibits the different electrochemical CO2 reduction products by following different electron pathways in aqueous electrolytes in the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale [34]. The equilibrium potentials of CO2RR and reaction products depend on pH and the number of electrons transferred. The high energy is required to activate the stable linear CO2 molecule to the bent CO2 – radical intermediate. The thermodynamic potential needed to form the CO2 – is −1.49 V vs. RHE [34]. The electrochemical CO2RR is a multielectron transfer process, and the reaction occurs at high overpotential. The CO2RR has sluggish kinetics rather than oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution, and HER involved in aqueous electrolytes. The equilibrium potentials of CO2RR are comparable with HER, and hydrogen (H2) is the major side product for CO2RR. From a thermodynamic point of view, the catalyst that increases the CO2RR activity and inhibits the HER activity should be favorable to adsorb *CO2 instead of *H. The bonding energy of *H should be weaker than that of *CO2 [9]. In CO2RR, the high selectivity for a particular value-added product is more beneficial to sidestep energy-wasting and simplify the product's separation. However, the high selectivity for a specific product is quite challenging due to the similar binding energy of the various reactions intermediates [67,76–79]. The product selectivity depends on different factors such as types of electrocatalysts, electronic and geometric structure, electrolyte solutions, pH of the electrolyte solutions, temperature, and reaction pressure [80]. For example, elements like Sn, Bi, Pd, Pb, and In have been demonstrated as high selectivity for formate formations. Similarly, elements like bulk Ag, Au, Zn, Cd, and Pd are highly selective for CO formations [67]. The long-term stability of the catalytic under a constant applied potential is another key parameter for practical applications. Recently, atomically dispersed active metal catalysts, SACs, have maximum atom efficiency, high activity, selectivity, and potential for electrochemical CO2RR. In most SACs, the major product for CO2RR is CO or HCOOH, and both are two electrons transfer processes. The formations of CO or HCOOH depend on which atom catalyst is attached to the catalytic surface (Fig. 3 a and b). If the carbon atom of the intermediate CO2 – radical is attached to the metal sites, the radical's oxygen atom would be protonated to form the *COOH intermediate. Similarly, if the intermediate oxygen atom is attached to the metal sites, *OCHO is intermediate. Further, the electron transfer and proton attachment convert *COOH intermediate to CO, whereas *OCHO intermediate gives HCOOH. Both experimental and theoretical calculations suggest that the transition metals (Ni, Co, Fe, Mn, and Zn) based SACs (TM-SACs) yield CO as the primary product during CO2RR. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation suggests that the alkaline-earth metals-based SACs produce HCOOH as the primary product instead of CO, which has not been explored experimentally yet [81]. 3 Understanding the intrinsic catalytic activity of SACs for CO2RR According to the thermodynamic point of view, a single atom cannot exist due to high surface energy and requires a well-confined substrate surface to stabilize. That is why a single atom is called married. The solid subtract has defects rich, wide edges, corner sites, distortions, large populations of surface reconstruction sites which are formed intentionally or unintentionally are good for anchoring the single atoms. The anchoring sites of subtracting play a major role in stabilizing the single atoms. The catalytic activity of SACs depends on both the homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. In the case of heterogeneous catalysts, the catalytic activity can be increased by regulating the electronic structure and engineering the number of active sites, and both can be achieved by forming composites alloying and engineering on the substrate [82–84]. The engineering strategy involves creating detects, reducing size, and increasing interface dominance properties. In a homogeneous catalyst, the catalytic activity depends on the charge of central metal atoms and the ligand's coordination environment [85,86]. Thus, the intrinsic catalytic activity of SACs can be improved by regulating the atomic radius of the metals, coordination environment around the metal centre, increasing the surface area, and defect engineering in the support catalysts, Lewis acidity, and basicity of the support catalysts and metal centre. The catalytic activity of SACs also depends on the percentage of metals loading and distributions of single atoms. The percentage of metal loading can be increased by increasing the support of the catalysts' surface area and porosity. The high surface and porous support can easily anchor the higher percentage of metal atoms on their surface. The defect engineering in support catalysts is also an important strategy for improving the percentage of metal atoms. The various defect sites of support catalysts easily anchor and stabilize single atoms. The defect-abundant support catalyst anchoring a single atom has strong metal-support interaction, different electronic arrangements, and coordination environment in comparison to defect-free supports catalysts. Thus, fundamental understanding is required in experimentally and theoretically how these parameters influence electrocatalytic activity. In recent years, several DFT simulations have been carried out to understand the relation between local atomic structure and electrocatalytic CO2RR property. Gong et al. performed the DFT simulation studies for CO2RR electrocatalysts based on porphyrin-containing SACs (M–N–C) by different metal centres, i.e., transition metal (TM-SAC) and alkaline earth metals (AM-SACs) [81]. For the TM-SAC, the primary product for CO2RR is CO instead of HCOOH (Fig. 3c). The formation of CO is dominated in Ti-based SACs in comparison to other TM-SACs. The electrochemical CO2RR always competes with HER due to the similar binding energy of *H, *COOH, and *CO reaction intermediates and close equilibrium potentials. Most of the TM-SACs is favorable for bonding with CO2 rather than H in the initial step. However, the overpotential (η) plot of CO and HER suggests that the Sc, Ti, and V-based SACs have HER dominating property and prevent the CO2RR compared to other TM-SACs. However, the volcano-type relationship between the η(CO) and ΔG(*CO) suggests that Ti and V-SACs have lower η values than other transition metals (Fig. 3d). The Ti and V-SACs have lower overpotentials but dominate HER activity, suppressing the catalytic activity towards CO2RR. The TM-SACs such as Co and Fe would exhibit excellent performance for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO with lower HER activity and comparable overpotentials with noble metal catalysts (Ag, Au). Back et al. made the theoretical calculation of SACs anchored on single vacancies defective graphene (M@sv-Gr) and double vacancies of defective graphene (M@dv-Gr) over a wide range of metals (M = Ag, Au, Co, Cu, Fe, Ir, Ni, Os, Pd, Pt, Rh or Ru) for electrochemical CO2RR [87]. Most of the metal prefers to bind dv-Gr in comparison to sv-Gr. All the M@sv-Gr and M@dv-Gr are more selective towards CO2RR and good tolerance towards HER due to the favorable adsorption of *COOH or *OCHO intermediates on the SACs surface. For Ni and Pt@dv-Gr, the reduction product is CH3OH. But in the case of Os and Ru@dv-Gr, the reduction product is CH4. The strong interaction of d-orbital and p-orbital of the metal and graphene is responsible for the higher catalytic activity. Liu et al. studied the wide range of transition metal SACs anchoring on tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) monolayers (TM–TCNQ SACs) electrochemical CO2RR [88]. The catalysts support TCQN as an electron acceptor and form a charge-transfer complex with metal atoms. All the TM–TCNQ SACs exhibit good inhibition towards HER. The reduction product of Sc and Ti–TCNQ is CH4, for V, Cr, Mn, Ni, and Cu–TCNQ based SACs, the reduction product is HCOOH, for Fe and Co–TCNQ based SACs, the dominant reduction product is HCHO and for Zn–TCNQ reduction product is CO. the strong bonding interaction between metals atom and support catalysts and change in the electronic structure are responsible for catalytic activity. The interaction between catalysts and reaction intermediate plays a vital role in the final product. 4 Synthetic strategies Synthesizing highly active and stable SACs are quite tricky and challenging. There are many challenges to their fabrication. The first major challenge is increasing the weight percentage of the metals loading, which can be achieved by increasing the surface and number of anchoring sites of the support catalysts. The second challenge is synthesizing uniform distribution of single atoms on the catalysts supports, and the third challenge is controlling the coordination environment of metal atoms. Both the challenge required a controlled fabrication procedure and advanced technology. Both top-down and bottom-up approaches have been adopted to develop SACs (Fig. 4 ). Most SACs are synthesized by a bottom-up approach such as atomic layer deposition, electrochemical deposition, photochemical reduction, etc. The preparation of a single isolated atom is quite thought-provoking due to high surface energy and instability. Therefore, inhibition strategies for accumulation or surface anchoring sites play a vital role in stabilizing SACs. Herein, we discuss the different synthesis processes for the fabrication of SACs and discuss the different synthesis processes' advantages and disadvantages. 4.1 Pyrolysis method The synthesis of a single atom on nanocarbon support by pyrolysis is the most accepted method. For this method, a variety of molecular precursors can be chosen to change the coordination environment of a metal atom, which is crucial for catalytic activity. Furthermore, this method makes it easy to optimize metal loading and different engineering substrate that affect electrocatalytic activity. A wide range of precursors such as graphene, organic polymers, heteroatom-based organic molecules, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent organic frameworks (COFs), etc., is used to synthesize SACs. The pyrolysis of transition metal porphyrins and phthalocyanines-based molecular precursors have been carried out at higher temperatures to synthesize M–N–C electrocatalysis. The M–N–C SACs have formed if the individual carbon and nitrogen precursor pyrolysis is carried out with metal ions at a higher temperature. The selection of molecular precursors, the porosity, and the structure of support catalysts are essential to synthesizing atomic M–N x –C x species. For example, Yuan et al. take the molecular precursor of pyrrole, phytic acid, and metal precursor (FeCl3) to synthesize Fe-N/P-C catalysts (Fig. 5 a) [89]. Pyrrole, phytic acid, and FeCl3 are polymerized to form a poly-pyrrole hydrogel in this synthesis process. The pyrolysis of the hydrogel was carried, followed by acid etching to form Fe-N/P-C catalysts. Li. et al. developed Ni–N4–C catalysts by two-step pyrolysis method by taking molecular precursor of dicyandiamide as a nitrogen source and glucose as a carbon source [90]. First, Ni-doped g-C3N4 was prepared by a lower temperature (550 °C) pyrolysis of dicyandiamide and nickel salt. Then, Ni-doped g-C3N4 was mixed with glucose, and pyrolysis was carried out at 1000 °C to synthesize Ni–N4–C catalysts. Zhang et al. have synthesized different Fe-N x sites by pyrolyzing different molecular precursors [91]. The pyrolysis of hemin and melamine mixture at higher temperatures produces the Fe-N4-C species, and by adding the graphene to this mixture, Fe-N5-C species are formed. The pyrolysis of organic polymers such as polypyrrole, polyaniline, polyacrylonitrile polydopamine with metal ion precursors at higher temperatures produces M−N–C-based SACs. For example, Varela et al. developed mono and bimetallic M–N–C SACs by pyrolysis of a metal decorated polyaniline polymer [92]. Graphene and heteroatom doped graphene are the best support catalysts for anchoring the different single atoms [93–95]. The oxygen-containing functional group of the graphene oxide (GO) has a high adsorption capacity towards the metal centre through electrostatic interactions. The concentration of metal ions precursors plays a vital role in restricting into single atoms. In heteroatom doped graphene, the strong interactions between heteroatoms and metal centres stabilize the SACs. Zhang et al. have shown the stability of Fe single atom anchored on N-doped graphene (Fe-N/G) [173]. In this process, the iron precursor (FeCl3) concentration is dispersed in the GO suspension and lyophilized to form GO/FeCl3 foam. The pyrolysis of foam was carried out in Ar/NH3 atmosphere to form Fe-N/G, where NH3 is used for the doping of nitrogen on the graphene sheet. The higher concentration of FeCl3 forms the iron nanoparticles. Zhang et al. synthesized Ru single atoms on nitrogen-doped graphene substrate by high-temperature pyrolysis method [96]. The nitrogen-doped graphene has been used as excellent support for developing different transition metal-based SACs (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Ru, Mn, Sc) [93–98]. The pyrolysis of MOFs has been considered a novel process for synthesizing different metal nanostructures such as metal oxides, carbides, bi-metallic alloys, and phosphides. The porous carbons with controllability of shape, size, porosity, composition, and diverse functionalities cab be derived from the pyrolysis of MOFs. Recently, the pyrolysis of MOFs has been considered an efficient process to synthesize different metal-based SACs [99–103]. The higher surface area, porosity, and heteroatoms help for uniform dispersion and stabilization of the SACs. Also, the coordination environment around the single atoms can be modified by altering the pyrolysis temperature. Different TM-SACs such as Co, Mn, Zn, Fe, Cu, Ni are successfully synthesized by high-temperature pyrolysis of different MOFs. For example, Yin et al. developed the single Co atoms on nitrogen-doped carbon (Co-N-C) with a higher metal loading of 4% by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 precursor [104]. In this synthesis process, the Zn+2 ion partially replaces the Co+2 ions from its coordination sites to expand the distance to prevent accumulation. Since Zn's melting point is low, the increase in pyrolysis temperature evaporates the Zn and forms the free N sites to anchor Co atoms. By prudently monitoring Co's molar concentrations, the materials with Co mostly in the form of single atoms could be achieved. The coordination environment around the single atoms depends on the pyrolysis temperature. The pyrolysis at 800, 900, 1000 °C produces the Co-N4, Co-N3, and Co-N2 sites. The CN fragments of Co (II)-imidazolate linkages are released with an increase in temperature, resulting in Co-N bonds' decay. Besides TM-SACs, noble metals SACs such as Pt, Pd, Au, Ru are also successfully fabricated. Thus, the synthesis of SACs, the pyrolysis method, has comparable advantages in controlling metal loading, scale-up production, and an easy process without sophisticated instruments. 4.2 Atomic layer deposition (ALD) This process is a bottom-up synthesis approach for synthesizing atomically precise design and control catalysts by the gas phase deposition method. The self-limiting control features can regulate the atomic size precisely and deposited in an atomic layer-by-layer fashion. Thus, the ALD technique has been used for developing precise control and uniform distributions of atoms on the support materials. The particle size and percentage of loading of SACs can easily be controlled by changing the number of cycles. The atomic size increases from a single atom to a nanoparticle by increasing the number of cycles. Using this ALD technique, Pt and Pd metal group single atoms are deposited on the carbon support [105,106]. For example, Sun et al. synthesized a single Pt atom on a graphene sheet (Fig. 5b) [107]. With an increasing number of cycles from 50 to 150 cycles, the atomic size increases from 0.5 nm to 4 nm, and atomic wt.% increases from 1.52 to 10 wt.%. Using the ALD technique, Yan et al. synthesized Pd single atoms on graphene support [106]. For graphene, the phenolic and carbonyl functional oxygen group acts as coordination sites for the deposition of a single metal atom during ALD. The nitrogen-doped graphene is also a suitable substrate for the deposition of Pt, the nitrogen atoms of graphene act as anchoring sites during ALD. Although this synthesis process is highly specific, large-scale productions remain a significant challenge. Also, the high cost and scalability issue hamper the large-scale production of SACs. 4.3 Photochemical reduction The nanoparticle is synthesized in solid-state conditions and at a lower temperature in photochemical reduction. In this method, the photons from UV-radiation and electronically excited states are responsible for the reduction [108,109]. For this method, atomic diffusion of the metal ions takes place in the solution. The metal ions precursors in the solution should confine the migration and random diffusion, and that can be achieved by freezing the precursor solutions. For example, Wei et al. synthesize Pt SACs by a unique iced photochemical reduction method (Fig. 5c) [110]. The precursor solution was frozen to the ice layer for the uniform distribution of metal ions. Then the solid ice layer was exposed to UV radiation to produce dispersed Pt atoms. Naturally, the ice lattice restricted the precursor molecule's spread during the synthesis, which prevented the nucleus formation during the reduction. By this process, the Pt SACs are successfully anchored on different substrates, including an amorphous carbon film, mesoporous carbon, graphene, multi-walled carbon nanotubes, TiO2 nanoparticles, and ZnO nanowires. Li et al. developed a solid-phase photochemical reduction method to synthesize Pt single atoms on N-doped porous carbon (NPC) substrate [111]. The heteroatom and abundant micropores NPC chemically anchor the Pt precursor, and in the presence of ultraviolet light, the Pt precursor is converted to Pt single atoms. Similarly, Ge et al. synthesized single-Pd atoms anchoring on TiO2 substrate (Pd SA/TiO2) by using in situ photochemical reduction method [112]. In the synthesis process, the homogeneous mixture, TiO2, and Pd salt solution are converted to ice solid with the help of liquid nitrogen. The Pd salt is adequately dispersed and settled on the TiO2 surface due to the strong interaction between oxygen and vacant orbitals of Pd. Then the ice solid was irradiated with Xenon light to produce single Pd atoms dispersion on TiO2 substrate Pd SA/TiO2. In the presence of Xe light, the excited TiO2 produces the photogenerated electrons, and that electron help to reduce the Pd+2 to a single Pd atom. The synthesized Pd, SA/TiO2 catalysts, exhibit the high selectivity for detection of chlorpyrifos and higher photocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction. Similarly, Liu et al. reported atomic dispersion of Pd atom on ultrathin TiO2 surfaces by photochemical methods [109]. 4.4 Wet chemistry method The wet chemistry methods are the most promising and frequently used synthesis route for the synthesis of SACs, and this is due to their low cost, feasibility, and large-scale productions. In the wet chemical synthesis approach, the metal ions precursor is adsorbed on the support catalysts through co-precipitation, impregnation/ion exchange, polymerization, etc. In the pyrolysis process, the metal ions precursor is converted to a single atom and supports catalysts to anchor catalysts sites. For this method, the strong interaction of metal ions and support catalysts prevent metal atoms' migration and aggregation. The support materials have a limited capacity to accumulate metal ion precursors. The higher concentration causes the accumulation to form a nanoparticle. So, the concentration of metal ion precursors plays a vital role in synthesizing SACs. To increase the metal loading and stabilize the single atom on the catalyst's support, the concentration of metal ions and selection of support catalysts play an important role. For example, Wei et al. have developed a series of metal SACs of Pt, Pd, Au, Rh, and Ir decorated on the FeO x (M/FeO x ) materials [113]. During the synthesis, metal ions precursor and ferric nitrate [Fe(NO3)3·9H2O] precursor were precipitated by sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) precipitation agent followed by a reduction in 10% H2/He atmosphere to format M/FeO x . Jiao et al. synthesized atom-pair catalyst (APC) Cu1 0-Cu1 x + on Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires [30]. First ultrathin Te nanowires are synthesized by a simple hydrothermal process. Using the galvanic displacement method, Pd was doped into the Te nanowires to form Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires. Further different Cu loading in the Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires was achieved by controlling the Cu precursors. The after successive alkaline and acidic wash APC Cu1 0-Cu1 x + on Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires was achieved. The catalysts exhibit a higher electrocatalytic activity towards CO2RR. Wan et al. decorated Au SACs on TiO2 nanosheet with a mass loading of 0.25% by a wet chemical approach [114]. Using deposition–precipitation process, the Au ions precursor was dispersed on the TiO2 surface, and then the materials were reduced in the H2/Ar atmosphere for Au single atom decorated TiO2 nanosheet. 4.5 Electrochemical deposition method Electrochemical deposition is a universal method for depositing single atoms on the catalyst support. The conventional three-electrode system has been used for this method, where the support catalysts are used as a working electrode (Fig. 5d). In the electrochemical approach, the SACs are synthesized by both cathodic and anodic deposition. The size of the particle and weight percentage of metal ions in the support catalysts can be controlled by optimizing the number of potential cycles and concentration of metals precursor in the electrolyte. For the deposition of Pt on the catalyst's support, the Pt wire used in the counter electrode is played as a Pt source. Pt wire is oxidized at anode and dissolute to the electrolyte in the higher oxidative potentials and finally redeposited in the working electrode. Both dissolution and redeposition are highly substantial in a strong acidic and alkaline environment. Using this single method, the atom has been deposited on different support catalysts like LDH, MoS2, Ca(OH)2, MnO2, Co0.8Fe0.2Se2, Graphdiyne, Mxene, etc. [115–118]. Zhang et al. have synthesized more than 30 different SACs using different metal ion precursors and support catalysts by cathodic and anodic deposition methods [115]. For cathodic deposition, the potentials varied from 0.10 to −0.40 V, and for anodic deposition, the potentials were varied from 1.10 to 1.80 V. Interestingly, the same metal SACs deposited by both cathodically and anodically have different electronic states, different mass loading, and exhibiting different electrocatalytic property. The size and percentage of metal loading were varied by changing the cycle scan, the concentration of metals, and the scan rate. Xue et al. fabricated Ni and Fe metal atoms on graphdiyne support by electrode depositions method. Ni (0) and Fe (0) single-atom are mainly around 1.23 and 1.02 Å [118]. Thus, this method has numerous advantages over another synthesis process. 4.6 Ball-milling process The ball milling technique is used to grind, blend, and mix the materials or catalysts, and it is a prevalent technique in powder technology. The ball's kinetic energy helps break and make chemical bonds or restructure the materials in this technology. The energy ball mill creates a high temperature and pressure inside the mill, which helps to modify the materials. Recently, the ball-mill method has been successfully employed to synthesize different SACs (Fig. 5e) [86,119,120]. For example, Deng et al. have synthesized Fe single atom on graphene matrix with metal loading of 2.7 wt% [120]. During the ball mill, the outside macrocyclic structure of phthalocyanine is demolished. As a result, the isolated FeN4 species are separated, and that interact with graphene to form graphene decorated FeN4 centres. By using this method, different graphene decorated transition metal single-atom has been synthesized. 5 Molecular strategies of SACs for improved CO2RR activity Different molecular strategies have been developed for isolated single atoms and support catalysts to enhance the CO2RR activity of SACs (Fig. 6 ). Such strategies are (1) regulating the coordination number of metal atoms; different coordination numbers exhibiting different CO2RR activity. For example, Co-N4, Co-N3, and Co-N2, sites exhibit different CO2RR activity towards the formations of CO, and the order of activity is Co-N2 > Co-N3 > Co-N4 [121]. Also, in comparison to Fe-N4 sites, the Fe-N5 sites exhibit more activity and are selective towards the formations of CO [91]. (2) Regulating the oxidation state of the central atom; ionic SACs are highly selective towards the formation of CO. Regulating the oxidation state indorsing reactant initiation, adsorption of the reaction intermediates, and finally helping the C–C coupling [122]. For example, Fe+3-N-C is highly active for CO2RR in comparison to Fe+2-N-C and Fe-N-C [28]. Similarly, the unusual Ni (I) valency state in A-Ni-NSG and A-Ni-NG catalysts is highly selective for the CO formations. (3) Creating vacancies defect or forming co-ordinately unsaturated sites modify the surrounding atoms' electronic structure and coordination environment. The vacancies defect lowers the energy reaction intermediate and helps to easy desorption of CO. For example, defect-rich Ni-SAC (Ni-N3-V) is more selective towards formations of CO than defect-free Ni-N4 and Ni-N3. (4) Synthesizing multimetal center; helps to overcome the limitation of individual moieties. For example, isolated diatomic Ni-Fe-N-C sites exhibit higher CO2RR activity than individual Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C sites [123]. (5) Types of metal centres; the atomic metal sites are generally considered as the active centre for CO2RR. Hence, the proper selection of atomic metal centre offers an unswerving and effective way to enhance the CO2RR activity of SACs. (6) Percentage of metals loading; since metal atomic sites are the catalytic active centre for CO2RR, increasing the percentage of metals loading increases the catalytic activity. High metal loading can be achieved by increasing the support catalysts' surface area, increasing the number of anchoring sites, and creating a defect in the subtract. Also, other molecular strategies such as the distribution of atomic metal sites, the surface area of the substrate, wide edges, and lewis acidity, and the basicity of the support catalysts enhance the electrocatalytic CO2RR activity [10,122,124]. 6 Techniques used for characterization of SACs The traditional nanomaterials characterization techniques such as XRD, Raman, TEM, SEM, UV–visible, etc., are not sufficient to understand the geometric and electronic properties of the SACs. The advanced materials characterization techniques such as scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS, including extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES)), and atom probe tomography (APT) (Fig. 7 ). The other characterizations, such as electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), Mossbauer spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and probe molecule-IR, are also used for providing useful information about SACs. All these characterizations are used together to understand the geometric and electronic properties of the SACs. The concept of heterogeneous catalysts was first invented by Thomas et al. in 1995 [125,126]. However, an in-depth analysis was hampered due to the absence of advanced characterization technology at that time. Identifying the geometric and electronic structure of the active centres in SACs plays a substantial role in the electrocatalytic process. Here, we will discuss some advanced characterization techniques used for SACs. 6.1 Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) is a commonly accepted technology to identify the isolated atom on the catalyst support. In History, in 1970, Crewe et al. reported both experimentally and theoretically that amazing the heavy uranium (U) single atoms in carbon substrate [127]. The annular-shaped dark-field (ADF) detector and emission electron apparatus are used for amazing. The apparatus allows the formations of the sub-nanometer electron beam, and the detector improves the signal-to-noise ratio. In the ADF-STEM method, the contrast of the image depends on the atomic number (Z) of the element and the crystallographic orientation of the materials. But imaging of crystalline single atomic particles or clusters is difficult. Howie’s group is projected to improve the detector's inner collection angle to decrease the diffraction contrast of crystalline particles and increase the Z contrast. The new imaging method is known as HAADF-STEM [128]. Thus, HAADF-STEM is highly sensitive to the atomic number of the elements. The different atoms having a similar atomic number may not be distinguished by HAADF-STEM. For example, N, O, P, and S atoms may not distinguish graphene or other carbon materials. The single-atom having a higher atomic number gets more scattered electrons at higher angles due to higher electrostatic interactions between the nucleus and the beam. It forms brighter spots compared to lower atomic number elements [129,130]. In M–N–C-based catalysts, metal atoms are visible with bright spots due to the large difference in atomic number between metal atoms and N/C. For example, Zhang et al. used HAADF-STEM to visualize dispersed Fe centers in HP-FeN4 catalysts [131]. The isolated Fe atoms were homogeneously distributed across the carbon framework (Fig. 8 a). Thus, HAADF-STEM is significant for atomic-level characterization to detect isolated atoms' exact location and distribution and distinguish from single atoms to metal nanoparticles and clusters on supported catalysts. Besides, this technique also helps to understand the surface structure of support materials. Further, the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM (AC-HAADF-STEM) can directly image the isolated atoms at a resolution of below 0.1 nm with a clear distinction of the isolated single atoms with brighter spots [132,133]. The AC-HAADF-STEM is also beneficial for the characterization and understanding of important mechanisms, morphology/structure of the isolated atom. The electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) also helps to predict the structural evidence of SACs. The EELS, combined with AC-HAADF-STEM, is the most powerful technique to detect geometrical information of the SACs. Chung et al. used AC-HAADF-STEM and corresponding EELS on isolated Fe atoms decorated on cyanamide and polyaniline's combined precursor to obtain the elemental mapping images of catalysts [134]. The AC-HAADF-STEM image suggests that the isolated Fe atoms are uniformly distributed carbon sheets with bright spots. The combined EELS with AC-HAADF-STEM analysis detects the active centre Fe-N x coordination environment on the carbon sheets. In the bright spots, the signal for both N and Fe are observed, and in the dark spots, no N or Fe signals were observed, signifying the coexistence in the form of Fe-N x coordination. The quantification of EELS data confirms the formations of Fe-N4 moiety on the carbon nanosheets (Fig. 8b and c). Similarly, the formation of atomic level Co-N x and Mn-N x coordination are also confirmed by EELS analysis [135,136]. 6.2 Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) STM is another commanding microscopic technique for the analysis of the geometric and electronic structure of the isolated atom anchored in the uniformly flat conductive substrate [50]. STM analysis's advantage is distinguishing the element with a close atomic number, i.e., distinguishing the nitrogen atoms from the carbon in N-doped graphene. Deng et al. identify the N-dopant in N-doped graphene using low-temperature STM [137]. In SACs, STM analysis visualizes the atomic-scale arrangement of the active centre on the catalytic surface. Bao et al. identify the atomic-resolution image of Fe-N4 active centre anchoring on the graphene support at low-temperature STM analysis [120]. The isolated Fe atoms surrounded by N and C atoms show a brighter spot than carbon atoms far away from the Fe-N4 active centre. This suggests the modification of the electronic structure of adjacent Fe surrounded atoms. (Fig. 8d) The STM image simulation confirms the formation of Fe-N4 active centre on the plane of graphene sheets and well agreements with the experimental results. (Fig. 8e) The scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS) was studied to confirm that the Fe-N4 active centre forms a strong bond with the graphene sheets' carbon atom. (Fig. 8f). Recently, the in situ environmental TEM (ETEM) technique that operates in gaseous or liquid conditions has the advantage over conventional TEM to directly analyze the structural evolution in single atoms catalysis in reactive conditions. The in situ ETEM analysis helps understand the single atoms' formation mechanism under reactive conditions and catalytic reaction mechanisms. For example, Wei et al. reported the dynamic in situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) analysis that noble metal nanoparticles can be converted to stable atomically dispersed isolated atoms above 900 °C in an inert atmosphere [103]. The competing sintering and atomization processes were observed while converting the noble metal nanoparticle to isolated atoms. Also, Zhao et al. investigate the isolated Fe atoms at graphene edges by the in situ ETEM analysis observation [138]. 6.3 X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) The microscopic characterizations are unable to provide detailed, convincing evidence about the formation of SACs. So, for the in-depth analysis of the information of the geometric, electronic, and coordination environment of the SACs, spectroscopic technique such as XAS significantly EXAFS and XANES analysis has been performed. The XAS has a higher atomic resolution than the microscopic technique, and it operates in the lower wavelength regions (1–0.01 nm). The EXFAS and XANES spectra are operated in different regions and give different information about the SACs. The XANES operated in the spectral region of −30 to 50 eV, whereas the EXAFS spectra operated in the range of 50–800 eV. The EXFAS spectra are obtained due to the interfering of outgoing and backscattered waves generated from the central atom and surrounded by neighboring atoms. The experimental EXAFS spectra's interpretation by the least-squares curve fitting gives information about the local atomic structure such as coordination number, inter-atomic distance, and structural defects. At the same time, the XANES spectra give information about the coordinating atom's arrangement and chemical state. The position of the edge energy in XANES spectra is sensitive to the oxidation state of the elements and can be quantified by comparing the oxidation states of known compounds. The shape and edge energy position of experimental XANES spectra gives information about the ligand's three-dimensional arrangement around the ligand's central metal atoms and types. Thus, the combined analysis of EXFAS and XANES is essential for structural and electronic information. The in situ and operando electrochemical XAS characterization is easier because of the lack of ultrahigh vacuum requirement, which is more important for understanding the relationship between the catalysts' structure–activity. 6.3.1 Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) The K-space in experimental EXAFS is originated from the summation of all interfering sine waves patterns scattered by all surrounded atoms. For a complete understanding of the atomic resolution of SACs, the EXAFS can be interpreted into the Fourier transformation (FT) and wavelet transformation (WT). In the FT-EXFAS analysis, the K space is converted into R space, and the signals are converted into radical function and directly allow the separation of the backscattering atoms. The WT EXFAS analysis is used to identify the atomic distribution, and it affords the resolution in both R-space and k-space. The qualitative WT-EXFAS analysis and quantitative FT-EXFAS analysis details coordination numbers, structural defects, inter-atomic distance, and types of coordinated atoms. To identify the atomic arrangement of transition metals (M = Ni, Co, Fe) anchored in N-doped holey graphene frameworks (M–NHGFs), Fei et al. used FT-EXAFS and WT-EXAFS analyses [94]. The FT-EXAFS study for references used metal oxides and foils. Fig. 9(a) shows that for Ni-NHGF, a major peak formed around 1.44 Å and a minor peak is formed around 2.01 Å, the major peak shorter than the Ni–O peak, and the minor peak partially overlapped with the Ni-Ni peak at 2.18 Å. In Fe-NHGF and Co-NHGF, similar behavior types were also observed, which causes problems for separating the scattering pair. Therefore, the WT-EXAFS analysis was performed for k 3-weighted M (Ni, Fe, Co) K-edge spectra at a resolution of 2 Å−1. (Fig. 9b) The analysis detects only one maximum intensity at 4.0 Å−1 corresponds to the M–N/O/C contributions and suggests the absence of a metal–metal bond, i.e., confirms the formation of SACs. The Ni–N, Ni–O, and Ni–C backscattering paths are used for fitting the EXAFS based on the WT-EXAFS analysis. (Fig. 9c and d) The fitting result concludes that the square-pyramidal geometry is formed for the Ni-N/O bonding in the first shell of Ni. Four carbon atoms and one oxygen atom in the axial direction are bonded in the second shell of Ni, suggesting Ni-N4C4 moiety's formation. The FT-EXAFS analysis helps to understand the change in coordination number around the probed atoms. For example, Wu et al. have analyzed Co sites' coordination environment by comparing the R space's intensity [139]. The prominent Co-N peak around 1.4 Å decreased significantly as the pyrolysis temperature increased from 800 to 1000 °C and that suggesting the decreased N atom around the Co centres (Fig. 9e). The fitted EXFAS data shows the Co–N coordination number to be 4.1, 3.1, and 2.2. Similarly, the change in Fe-N coordination number around the Fe centre is also studied by Pan et al. [140]. The decrease in Fe-N coordination in R-space with an increase in temperature suggests a reduction in Fe-N coordination. Thus, the combination of FT-EXAFS and WT-EXAFS analysis is a powerful characterization technique for understanding the SACs. Though EXAFS is extensively used to identify SACs, the standard deviation is still 20% for determining the coordination number. And also, there are other basic deficiencies in the EXAFS analysis [141–143]. 6.3.2 X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) In addition to the EXAFS analysis, the XANES spectra give a more precise idea about the electronic 3D structure of SACs. Generally, XANES spectra consist of three regions, i.e., pre-edge, edge, and post-edge, from lower energy to higher energy. The pre-edge peak gives information about the formation of the hybrid and symmetry of the metal sites. The edge peak provides information about the valency state of anchoring atoms, and the post-edge peak gives information about geometry around the metal centre. For the SACs, the absorption edge energy of XANES spectra is in between the metallic and oxidized reference because the oxidation state of SACs is neither oxidized nor metallic. The oxidation state of SACs can be determined by quantitative analysis from the shift of absorption edge location. Generally, for the higher oxidation SACs, the absorption edge peak location would move toward the higher energy. To study Ni atom's oxidation state in Ni-SACs with (A-Ni-NSG) and without (A-Ni-NG), the addition of a sulfur Yang et al. used XANES analysis [27]. The XANES data of A-Ni-NSG and A-Ni-NG is compared with Ni-foil and Ni-Pc. The inflection point comparison from the second-derivative spectrum of Ni K-edge suggests that Ni atom oxidation state in A-Ni-NSG and A-Ni-NG SACs was +1 3d9 configuration (Fig. 10 a). Ni (I) atoms' unusual oxidation state is due to the lower electronegativity of pyridinic N and S relative to the pyrrolic N in Ni(ii)Pc. Moreover, the characteristic features of A-Ni-NSG and A-Ni-NG XANES spectra are similar to Ni(ii)Pc and only change in relative intensities and edge positions, suggesting the distorted D 4 h symmetry around the Ni atoms. Gu et al. compared the Fe K-edge XANES of Fe+3-N-C with the reference sample of Fe2O3, Fe+3-TPPCl, FeO, and Fe-foil to evaluate the Fe atom's oxidation state in the Fe+3-N-C catalysts [28]. The binding energy and absorption edge position of Fe+3-N-C is close to Fe2O3 and Fe+3-TPPCl, suggesting the +3 oxidation state of the Fe atom in Fe+3-N-C catalysts (Fig. 10b). To estimate Fe's oxidation state in the Fe-ISA/SNC catalysts, Li et al. compared the Fe K-edge XANES of Fe-ISA/SNC with the reference sample of Fe2O3, FeS2, FeO, and Fe-foil [144]. The absorption edge position of Fe-ISA/SNC shows in between Fe2O3 and FeO suggests the oxidation state of Fe in Fe-ISA/SNC is in between +2 and +3. Xie et al. studied Sn's oxidation state in single-atom Sn δ + on N-doped graphene by analyzing the K-edge XANES spectra [145]. The absorption edge positions of single-atom Sn δ + on N-doped graphene shows in between the Sn foil and SnO2 nanoparticles, i.e., the oxidation state of Sn δ + is between 0 to 4. Similarly, Li et al. determine the oxidation state of Mn-NC catalysts from the analysis of XANES spectra. Mn-NC's edge peak is very close to MnO but far away from MnO2, suggesting that the oxidation state of Mn is +2 in Mn-NC [136]. Besides the chemical state analysis, the XANES spectra were also used to study the probed atom's geometry. To understand the electronic structure of anchoring sites in Fe-N-C catalysts, Zitolo et al. performed the XANES fitting (Fig. 10c–f) [146]. When the authors consider the FeN4 and FeN2+2 moiety in the graphene sheets for simulation, the theoretical spectra display very poor agreement with the experimental spectra. The agreement was slightly improved when the author examined the FeN4C12 moiety. In FeN4C12 moiety, the author first assessed using adsorbed oxygen on end-on configuration; a significant change was observed among simulated and experimental spectra. An excellent agreement was observed when another oxygen atom was attached in an axial direction. Also, the O2 attached side-on to the FeN4C12 moiety gives a good understanding of the experimental result. Thus, porphyrin-like FeN4C12 active sites with two adsorbed oxygen atoms yield an excellent deal among the empirical and theoretical XANES data. 6.4 Atom probe tomography (APT) The STEM analysis of SACs may not reflect the real atomic-scale distribution due to its 2D projections and low resolution. The APT analysis is the solution to the limitation of STEM analysis. The APT is a three-dimensional imaging technique and gives an elemental composition analysis in the atomic-scale resolution of the SACs. The APT works in the resolution of 0.1–0.3 nm in-depth and 0.3–0.5 nm laterally. In the APT experiment, high voltage is applied to the very sharp needle-shaped tip placed in a high vacuum chamber, and the needle is intended towards the detector. The sample temperature is reduced to 20–100 K. A 1–2 kV voltage pulse is applied to the tip atom, converted into ions. The ions are captured in time-of-flight mass spectrometers. The mass spectrum detects the element in the corresponding materials. The chemical composition of the 3D atomic-scale materials can be attained by model calculation merging the above data. The electronic structure identification of SACs is the key factor in understanding their electrocatalytic property. Even if the APT characterization technique cannot deliver the meticulous structure of the single-atom sites, still considered the best method for detecting the coordination environment in SACs. For example, Jiang et al. utilized the APT characterization technique to identify Ni moieties' coordination environment in graphene sheets [147]. The APT analysis suggests that only 0.2% of Ni atoms are bonded to N atoms, and Ni atoms are coordinated to graphene vacancies. The higher catalytic activity is due to the Ni atom's coordination with graphene vacancies rather than Ni-N coordination. However, APT characterization is explored in single atoms sites, still a powerful technique like HAADF-STEM and XAS analysis. 6.5 Infrared (IR) spectroscopy Infrared spectroscopy is an important, powerful site-specific characterization technique for identifying functional groups. This technique provides the atomic and molecular level information of reaction alleyways, intermediates formed, and the local structure of the active centre. For SACs, this technique insights into the structures of active sites, properties of single metals centres such as oxidation state, and coordination environment. This is because the change in dipole moment between adsorbed molecules and metals sites is sensitive to local atomic structure and electronic environments. To identify the properties of single metal centers on various supported catalysts, IR spectroscopy with probing molecules such as CO, NO, H2, and CH4 and CO is frequently used. The probing molecule adsorbed on the metal sites causes the change in vibrational frequency and intensity of the adsorbed molecule's IR spectra, which deduced the properties of single metal centers. For example, to distinguish between Ptiso and Ptmetal, De Rita et al. used IR spectra of CO adsorbed materials of Pt on TiO2 [148]. The COad stretching frequency of Ptiso is different than that of Ptmetal. The result was also confirmed by IR-STEM analysis. The CO adsorption combined with IR spectroscopy can distinguish between the Pt single atom and Pt nanoparticle [149]. The COad stretching frequency for CO adsorbed single Pt atom is 2088 cm−1, which is different from that for Pt nanoparticles (2020 cm−1) and Cu nanoparticles (2093 cm−1) (Fig. 11 ). Jiang et al. used CO probe combined with attenuated total reflection (ATR)-IR spectroscopy to study the local atomic structure of isolated Ni atoms anchoring on graphene layers [147]. For isolated Ni atoms, the absence of bridged bonded CO stretching frequency that appeared at ∼1900 cm−1 for Ni film suggests the absence of adjacent Ni atoms. Also, lowering the CO stretching frequency of linear-bonded CO compared to Ni film suggests local atomic and structures changes. The in situ FTIR spectra analysis is quite helpful for observing the reaction intermediates of the CO2 reduction product. Zu et al. used in situ FTIR spectroscopy to detect the intermediate product for the conversion of CO2 to formate for the catalysts isolated Sn δ + anchoring on N-doped graphene [145]. At the potential of above 0.74 V versus SCE, the peak appeared at 1539 cm−1 assigned to the asymmetric OCO stretches of HCOO-ion. In addition to that the new peak appeared at 1273 and 1694 cm−1 is assigned for the CO2 − radical, the peaks around 1460 and 1520 cm−1 is due to CO3 2− ions, which is the vital intermediates product of CO2RR. All the above results conclude that IR-spectroscopies are important for identifying the reaction mechanism of different electrochemical reactions and structure of active sites of different SACs. 6.6 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is used to detect vibrational, rotational, and other low-frequency modes and complement FTIR spectroscopy. In Raman spectroscopy, a different source of monochromatic light such as visible, near IR, near-ultraviolet range, and X-rays in the form of laser is being used. The incident photons interact with the materials and cause inelastic scattering. The shift in energy between the incident and scattered photons gives evidence about the vibrational modes of the system, and it is sensitive to the change in polarizability of molecules. Raman spectroscopy gives information about chemical structure, phase, polymorphism, intrinsic stress/strain, impurities, and active site-intermediate binding. Raman spectrum is a chemical fingerprint for a specific material and is used to identify a material or can be used to separate it from others. Raman analysis combined with electrochemistry provides real-time spectroscopic analysis for given electrochemical reactions. Thus, operando/in situ Raman spectroscopic analysis is help full to studying the structural change and reaction pathway of an electrochemical reaction [150]. For example, Dutta et al. performed in situ Raman spectroscopic analysis to study the change in oxidations state of SnO2 nanoparticles during electrochemical CO2RR [151]. The SnO2 nanoparticle exhibits the three characteristics of Raman bands at 482, 623, 726 cm−1 and corresponds to the Eg, A1g, and B2g modes of vibrations, and peak 623 cm−1 is characteristic peak SnO2. In electrochemical CO2RR, by applying the potential of −1 V vs. Ag/AgCl at the pH = 9.7 electrolyte, the intensity of the 623 cm−1 peaks is slightly reduced, suggesting a slight reduction of SnO2. When more negative potential −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl has been applied, the intensity of the 623 cm−1 peaks is completely reduced, suggesting a complete reduction of SnO2 to Sn. Moreover, the faradic efficiency for the formations of formate ions is dramatically decreased. Similar observations were also observed in electrolytes having pH 8.5 and 12. To find out the origin of the higher electrocatalytic CO2RR activity for Ni–N4–C single-atom catalyst, Liu et al. used the operando Raman spectra [152]. The Ni–N4–C SACs with uniform active sites were synthesized by grafting the nickel (II) 2,9,16,23-tetra(amino) phthalocyanine (Ni-TAPc) on a carbon nanotube. The catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity and selectivity towards the conversion of CO2 to CO. To understand the origin of the catalytic active sites author made the operando Raman spectra analysis. In the Raman spectra, Ni-TAPc catalysts exhibit two major peaks at ∼182 and ∼244 cm−1, which were allocated to isoindole deformation and Ni–N vibration, respectively. In the Ar-saturated KHCO3 electrolyte at the potential of more than 0.57 V vs. RHE, the Ni–N vibration is shifted to a lower wavelength suggesting the change of oxidation state of Ni from +2 to +1 preceding to CO2RR. The shifting of the Ni–N band was not observed in the CO2 saturated KHCO3 electrolyte. A similar result was also observed at the potential of 0.37 V vs. RHE. The above result concludes that Ni+ donates its lone pair to activate the CO2 and instantaneously convert it to Ni2+. Thus isolated Ni+ center is the catalytic active-sites for CO2RR. 6.7 Other technique The other characterizations, such as XPS, and probe molecule-IR Mossbauer spectroscopy, EPR, are also used for providing useful information about SACs. The XPS analysis is a surface-sensitive technique that has been extensively used to determine the presence of surface elements and the valence state of specified elements in the high-resolution spectrum. The XPS analysis is not proficient to determining the atomic dispersion of metal sites [65]. However, it is extensively used for SACs to study the oxidation state, coordination environment, difference in metals loading, heteroatom doping, etc., by measuring the energy of core-level electron and energy shifts. All these properties have been correlated to the electrocatalytic activity to understand the reaction mechanism and catalytic active sites. Zhao et al. used XPS to determine the electronic structures Cu-SA/NPC of SACs for understanding the active sites for CO2RR [153]. They reported that the concentration of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N contents also control the CO2RR product. The XPS analysis revealed that Cu-SA/NPC is riched with higher pyrrolic N contents, converting CO2 into multiple products such as formic acid, acetic acid, methanol, ethanol, and acetone with acetone as a major product. To understand the active sites for ORR, Peng et al. used XPS analysis to determine the electronic structures Fe–N–C type of SAC [154]. The deconvoluted N 1s and Fe 2p spectrum suggest that the Fe δ+ cations are coordinated to the N dopants on the support, and the Fe δ +-N x species act as catalytic active sites for ORR. By using XPS, Yang et al. found that the Ni metal center is in a low-valence state (1+) in Ni-based SACs [27]. The (quasi-)operando XPS studies under the CO2RR environments were able to distinguish the activated CO2 δ − and physically adsorbed CO2 on the Ni-SACs surface. The EPR analysis is an important characterization technique in surface chemistry and helps detect the paramagnetic species that consists of unpaired electrons. The in situ or quasi-in situ EPR analysis is carried out at room temperature, and pressure and lower temperature EPR analysis generally improve the improving resolution and spectral intensity. It gives information about electronic structures, radical ions, changes in oxidation states, interaction with the reactant, etc. In the case of transitions metal catalysts, the formations of vacancies and anchoring of single atoms are also confirmed by EPR analysis [6]. The unsaturated coordination sites and vacant sites on transitions metal catalysts anchoring the single atoms act as catalytic active sites for the particular reactions. The coordination between the single atoms and the support catalysts is also confirmed by EPR analysis. For example, Jiang et al. confirm the interaction between a single Pt atom and Co3O4 by EPR analysis [155]. They compare the EPR spectra of single atom Pt1/Co3O4 catalyst, NPs Pt/Co3O4, and Co3O4. The increase in the intensity of the Co+2 peak for the Pt1/Co3O4 catalyst suggests the higher oxygen vacancies and strong interaction between Pt single atom and Co3O4. The EPR analysis also helps to predict the oxidation state of the single atoms. Yang et al. used EPR spectra to detect the presence of unpaired electrons of Ni (I) species in A-Ni-NSG catalysts [27]. To determine the change in the oxidation state of Cu and Ti in Cu1/TiO2 SAC during the photoactivation cycle, Lee et al. use the low-temperature EPR analysis [156]. Before photoactivation, the sample gives the strong EPR spectra of Cu+2. However, after photoactivation, the peak completely disappears, and a small signal of Ti+3 has appeared. The EPR spectra are returned to the initial state when treated with oxygen. The above result suggests that photogenerated electrons simultaneously reduce the Cu2+ and Ti4+ ions. 7 Electrochemical CO2 reduction on single-atom catalysts Theoretical studies suggest that a wide range of SACs based on transition metals, noble metals, and alkaline earth metals are highly active for electrochemical CO2 reductions. Experimentally, some SACs are reported. This review discussed the 1st-row transition metals (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Zn, Sn) based single atoms for electrochemical CO2RR application in an aqueous solution. The Ni and Fe-based SACs are the most extensively studied, among other elements. 7.1 Ni single-atom catalysts (Ni-SACs) At a large potential window, the bulk Ni-based catalysts such as oxide, hydroxide, metallic nickel, etc., exhibit poor catalytic activity towards electrochemical CO2RR [157]. This is due to Ni's poisoning by CO and strong absorption energy for Ni (111) face [158,159]. Recently, It has been observed that in the Ni-based SACs, Ni active centre decreases the CO poisoning and activates the CO2 molecule, and that helps to increase the activity and selection of the CO2RR [160–163]. In Ni-SACs, Ni single atom will prefer to coordinate with N instead of C due to larger electronegative difference, and the strong interaction between Ni and N will create Ni-N x species [164]. The Ni-N x act as active sites for electrochemical CO2RR. Yang et al. synthesized low valent Ni (I) single atom anchored on the N-doped graphene matrix with and without S atoms and presented as A-Ni-NSG and A-Ni-NG [27]. The catalyst synthesis was carried out by two pyrolysis processes (600 and 900 °C) by taking the melamine molecular precursor as the nitrogen source, amino acid as both nitrogens and sulfur, and Ni acetate as a metal source. The molecular precursor melamine is polymerized to form void-rich carbon nitride (g-C3N4) in the synthesis mechanism. Subsequently, the functional –NH2 group donated the electron to the electrophilic Ni+2 and reduced it to a lower oxidation state metal centre. At higher temperatures, the stabilized Ni atom acts as the centre to catalyze graphene sheets' formation. The weight percentage of Ni in A-Ni-NG and A-Ni-NSG is 4.6 and 2.8, respectively. The synthesized catalysts have a 2D structure with a smooth surface. The HAADF-STEM image confirmed the dispersion of Ni atom on the 2D sheet. The isolated Ni atom with a valency state of +1 with 3d 9, S = 1/2 configurations is confirmed by Ni K-edge XANES and EPR spectra. FT-EXAFS spectra confirm the absence of Ni–Ni bonding on the isolated atoms, and the isolated Ni atom is coordinated to four nitrogen atoms (Ni-N4). In A-Ni-NG, the Ni(I) active centre is coordinated to four pyridinic-N atoms, and in A-Ni-NSG, the Ni (I) active centre is coordinated to three pyridinic-N atoms and one S atom. The thermodynamic stability of Ni(I) is lower as compared to Ni (0) and Ni (II). The catalysts A-Ni-NSG exhibit higher catalytic activity and selectivity toward reducing CO2 to CO compared to A-Ni-NG. The catalysts A-Ni-NSG exhibit an earlier onset potential, a higher current density of 115 mA cm−2, and higher mass activity of 1150 A gcatalyst −1. At the potentials of −0.5 V (vs. RHE), the catalysts exhibit the faradic efficiency of 97% for the formation of CO. The catalysts also exhibit a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 14800 h−1 at an overpotential of 0.61 V. The catalysts also exhibit long-term stability up to 100 h with 98% of retention of initials current. The higher catalytic activity of A-Ni-NSG is due to the non-symmetric ligand strength and distorted structure around Ni (I) centre. The operando XAS analysis was carried out to understand the adsorption and activation of CO2 in the catalytic surface (Fig. 12 a and b). In CO2 saturated KHCO3 solution, the Ni K-edge spectra shifted towards higher energy (0.04 eV) at OCV, suggesting the increase in the oxidation state of Ni atoms, and this is due to the electron transfer from Ni(I) to 2p orbital of carbon in CO2 to convert CO2 −. In CO2 reduction at the potential of −0.7 V, the Ni K-edge spectra shifted towards lower energy suggesting the recovery of oxidation state in Ni(I). In FT-EXAFS analysis, the increased intensity of major peak attributed to an influence from the Ni–C bond that overlapped with the Ni–N bond and shift towards longer length in CO2 reduction suggests expanding Ni–N bond. Recently, M–N x –C-based catalysts have attracted attention for electrochemical CO2 reduction. The strong coordination environment and the unique structure of the M–N x unit favored the reaction kinetics, lowering the adsorption energy of intermediate and bringing the high activity and selectivity towards CO2RR. Using the topochemical transformation strategy, Li et al. synthesized Ni-SACs materials with a high yield of Ni-N4 sites [90]. In the synthesis process, the material Ni-doped g-C3N4 is prepared by pyrolysis of dicyandiamide, NH4Cl, and NiCl2 mixture. The materials are then dispersed in a glucose solution to form a carbon layer and reduce the accumulation of Ni atoms. Then the pyrolysis of carbon-coated Ni-doped g-C3N4 was carried out at 1000 °C to form Ni-SACs (Ni-N4-C) with the content of Ni-N4 sites. The strong interaction between isolated Ni atom and four pyridinic-N atoms makes the Ni-N4 units planer structure. The Ni-SACs having Ni-N4 sites exhibit high catalytic activity and selectivity towards reducing CO2 to CO. The catalysts achieve the current density of 28.6 mA cm−2 for the formation of CO with maximum faradic efficiency of 99% at the potential of −0.81 V. The catalytic activity of Ni-N4-C decreased by adding catalytic poison SCN− to the electrolyte solution that suggests Ni atoms coordinated to N and Ni-N4, acts as the active centre. Further, DFT calculation suggests that Ni-N4 units are lower the formation energy of reaction intermediate *COOH (Fig. 12c). The surface engineering on the supported catalyst also increases the catalytic activity and selectivity towards CO2 reduction: Li and co-worker synthesized Ni-SACs from ZIF-8 by high-temperature pyrolysis methods [165]. The Ni precursor is dispersed in ZIF-8, and Ni ions are restricted within the pores of ZIF-8 and in high-temperature pyrolysis form isolated Ni atoms anchoring on N-doped carbon (Ni-SACs/N-C) with metal loading of 1.53%. In Ni-SACs/N-C, the Ni atom is coordinated to three N atoms and one carbon atom and forms (Ni-N3-C) active species. The catalysts Ni-SACs/N-C with active Ni-N3 species achieve the current density of 10.48 mA cm−2 for CO formation at the overpotentials of 0.89 V. The catalysts achieve the FE of 71.9% and an excellent turnover frequency of 5273 h−1. The excellent catalytic activity of Ni-SACs/N-C is attributed to the strong interaction and lower coordination number. Rong et al. introduce the vacancy defect in the SACs [166]. The defect-rich Ni-SAC (Ni-N3-V) was synthesized on the carbon cloth. In this synthesis process, the lower temperature (500 °C) pyrolysis was carried out, taking cyanuric acid (CA) and 2,4-diamino-6-phenyl-1,3,5-triazine (DPT) and nickel salt formed a mixed coordinated geometry (O/N) of Ni (II). But, high temperature (800 °C) pyrolysis removes the weaker Ni-O coordination and forms vacancy-defect Ni SAC (Ni-N3-V). The as-synthesized catalyst, Ni-N3-V, exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity towards CO2 conversion. The catalyst achieves a higher current density (65 mA cm−2) and a higher FE of 90% at the potential −0.9 V vs. RHE. The catalysts achieve a larger TOF value (1.35 × 105 h−1) than other reported catalysts. The catalytic activity of Ni-N3-V is larger than Ni-N4-C. The author has made the DFT calculations to understand the origin of higher catalytic activity in Ni-N3-V. The three optimized structures of Ni-N4, Ni-N3, and Ni-N3-V are used for calculations (Fig. 12d–f). The reaction path for the conversion of CO2 to CO is present in (Fig. 12g). The free energy diagram suggests that the Ni-N3-V catalyst lowers the formation energy of *COOH intermediate and desorption of CO, which plays a major role in enhancing the electrocatalytic CO2RR (Fig. 12h). Graphene is the best choice as a supported catalyst because of its high conductivity, 2D morphology, high chemical resistance, and inert towards HER. The single metal atom can easily anchor on the defect sites of graphene and heteroatom (N, S, P) doped graphene and significantly increase metal loading concentration. Su et al. synthesized Ni-N x graphene (Ni-N-Gr) catalyst by rapid pyrolysis, taking the Ni precursor and graphene oxides (GOs) for 1 min at 900 °C to avoid aggregation [167]. The size of the metal atoms is >1 nm, with a metal loading of 2.2%. The Ni-N-Gr catalyst exhibits high activity and selectivity for the conversion of CO2 to CO. The Ni-based nanoparticle catalyzes HER exclusively under conditions of CO2 reduction. In contrast, Ni-SACs suppress the formations of CO over H2. Jiang et al. anchored Ni single atom on 2D graphene matrix (Ni-N-G) and applied to electrochemical reduction of CO2 to high selectivity CO [93]. The author assembles an anion membrane electrode to prevent water contact and increase the CO2 mass transport. The electrode exhibits the current density of 50 mA cm−2 with CO selectivity of 97% with a high TOF of 59 s−1 at a cell voltage of 2.78 V. The author compares the CO2 reduction activity of Ni-N-G with NG (N-doped graphene) and Ni nanoparticles. Both NG and Ni NPs exhibit very poor catalytic activity and stability towards CO2RR, suggesting Ni-N x sites are responsible for the catalytic reduction. Cheng et al. report that without nitrogen doping, the activity and selectivity of Ni-SACs for CO2 reduction is less than 10 % [168]. Compared to N-doping with Ni-N x , coordination enhances up to above 90%. Wang and his co-worker use 3D atom probe tomography to identify the single atom anchoring sites in graphene [147]. The author decorates Ni-SACs on defect graphene by the carbonization process. The tomography analysis suggests that only 0.2% of Ni single atoms are directly coordinated to nitrogen, and 99.8% of a single atom is coordinated to a carbon atom of the defect graphene. The catalysts exhibit high activity and selectivity for the conversion of CO2 to CO. The catalysts exhibit a faradic efficiency of above 90% and a current density of 60 mA mg−1 for CO production. The DFT studies suggest that Ni-SACs have a higher density of state around the Fermi level in comparison to Ni (111) surface and that decreasing CO binding energy and indorse the generation of CO. Though graphene has several advantages over other support catalysts, the limitation of the graphene sheet for gas reduction is the blockage of the gas diffusion pathway due to its layer-by-layer stacking. Zheng et al. developed Ni-SACs are anchoring on nitrogen-doped activated carbon (Ni-NCB) by a straightforward and accessible method [169]. The catalysts Ni-NCB exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance to reduce CO2 to CO. The catalysts achieve the current density of 100 mA cm−2 with faradic efficiency of ∼99% at a potential of −0.681 V and ∼100% generation of CO with H2 generation below 1%. In summary, several strategies have been developed for the synthesis of Ni-SACs on different support catalysts with high metal loading and increased activity and selectivity towards CO2RR (Table 1 ). 7.2 Co single-atom catalysts (Co-SACs) The cobalt-based compounds such as CoO, Co3O4, metallic Co, Co-organic complex, etc., have been demonstrated as efficient electrocatalytic for CO2RR. These catalysts have high activity and selectivity towards forming formic acid (HCOOH) instead of carbon monoxide CO. Gao et al. achieved high selectivity (90%) for forming formic acid by taking partials to oxidize the cobalt layer [190]. The cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPC), Co porphyrins, and Co-SACs have high activity and selectivity towards the two-electron reduction of CO2 to CO [139,191]. In Co-based SACs, the strong metal–ligand interaction and coordination environment of the isolated atoms play a major role in enhancing the activity and selectivity for two-electron reduction of CO2 to CO. The catalytic activity of single atom Co-N x -C species depends on the coordination number of the metal atoms. The lower is the coordination number higher is the catalytic activity. Wang et al. synthesized a series of Co-N x species with different coordinate environments and compared the CO2RR activity [139]. In the synthesis process, the bi-metallic (Co/Zn) ZIF are synthesized at room temperature, followed by pyrolysis at a different temperature to produce different coordination of cobalt SACs. The pyrolysis temperature at 800, 900, and 1000 °C formed as Co-N4, Co-N3, and Co-N2, respectively. An increase in pyrolysis temperature decreases the Co-N coordination. The HAADF-STEM image confirms the atomic dispersion of isolated Co atoms, and the red circle indicates the isolated cobalt atoms. EXFAS and XANES analysis confirm the different coordination numbers around the Co atom. The Co-N2 species shows high catalytic activity in comparison to Co-N4, Co-N3, and Co nanoparticles. At the overpotentials of −0.63 V, the species Co-N2 achieve the current density of 18.1 mA cm−2, 23.3, and 7.3 times higher than Co-N4 Co-N3, respectively (Fig. 13 a). The Co-N2 species exhibit the FECO of 94% at a lower potential of −0.68 V, which is higher than Co-N3 (63% at −0.53 V) and Co-N4 (4.2% at −0.83 V) (Fig. 13b). The Co-N2 catalysts have a high TOF value of 33000 h−1 at the potential of −0.78 V, which is relatively higher than the Co-N4 catalysts (84 h−1 at −0.83 V). The higher catalytic activity of Co-N2 sites is due to the lowering in metal coordination and increase in the number of unoccupied 3d orbitals in Co atoms, which causes the reduction of adsorption energy of the intermediate CO2 − and increases CO formation rate. As a result, the catalysts with Co-N2 sites exhibit higher catalytic activity. The DFT calculation suggests that the Co-N4 sites have higher adsorption energy for CO2 −* and H* intermediate than Co-N2 sites, indicating sluggish reaction kinetics for both CO2RR and HER. But the lower adsorption energy of H* in comparison to CO2 −* suggests the higher HER reaction on Co-N4 sites. The above result indicates that the inert species Co-N2 exhibit higher activity and selectivity to reduce CO2 to CO. The higher catalytic activity of Co-N2 species is also confirmed by Song et al., who developed isolated cobalt atoms with Co-C2N2 sites [192].
