The catalysts exhibit 100% of FE at 1 V with the formation rate of ≈425 mmol g−1h−1. That concludes that Co-N2 moieties are highly active and selective towards CO2 reduction. Pan et al. synthesized isolated Co atom catalysis with Co-N5 moieties anchored on hollow N-doped porous carbon spheres (HNPCSs) [177]. The uniform hollow spheres are formed without aggregations of Co atoms. The XANES and EXAFS analysis suggest no Co-Co coordination, and the coordination number of an isolated Co atom is 5, i.e., the catalysts possess Co-N5 sites. Co-N5/HNPCSs achieve lower onset overpotentials and higher current density for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO. The catalysts Co-N5/HNPCSs achieve the high faradic efficiency of 99.2% and 99.4% at −0.73 and −0.79 V vs. RHE, respectively, which is quite higher than CoPC and other transitions metal-based catalysts M–N5/HNPCSs (M = Fe, Ni, Cu) (Fig. 13c and d). The Co–N4/HNPCSs and Co–N3/HNPCSs sites were also synthesized by pyrolysis of the Co–N5/HNPCSs catalysts at a 400 and 600 °C, respectively, to reveal the effect of the coordination environment on catalytic activity. The faradic efficiency for the formation of CO decreases with decreases in Co-Nx coordination. Co–N4 and Co–N3 sites' faradic efficiency is 90% at −0.57 to −0.79 V, respectively, suggesting a reasonably CO2RR activity. The in-situ XAS analysis indicates that an isolated atom's appropriate electronic structure plays a vital role (Fig. 13e). The DFT result reveals that the Co–N5 moieties act as leading active sites for CO2 activation and rapidly form the reactions intermediate and desorption of CO compared to other M–N5 (M = Fe, Ni, Cu) moieties (Fig. 13f). All the above results conclude that the electronic structure of Co-SACs plays a major role in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction activity. The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction activity of different Co-SACs is summarised in Table 1. 7.3 Fe single-atom catalysts (Fe-SACs) Like Ni and Co-based SACs, Fe-SACs are also extensively studied for CO2RR. The Fe-N x -C sites are also responsible for two-electron paths for the conversion of CO2 to CO [193,194]. In the case of Fe NPs, the two-electron HER suppresses the conversion of CO2 to CO, whereas, for Fe-SACs, the reduction of CO2 to CO suppresses the HER. The isolated Fe atom anchored on nanocarbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotube, conductive carbon, etc., have been widely used to convert CO2 to CO. For example, Zhang et al. synthesized the isolated Fe atom on N-doped graphene (Fe/NG) by pyrolyzing the Fe ions adsorbed graphene oxide in Ar/NH3 atmosphere at the temperature of 750 °C (Fe/NG-750) [176]. The Fe/NG-750 catalysts consist of isolated Fe atoms with rich Fe-N4 sites and are confirmed by HAADF-STEM image and XAS analysis. The catalysts are also synthesized at different pyrolysis temperatures, and at higher temperatures, the Fe atoms aggregate and form Fe nanoparticles. The catalytic Fe-N4 sites act as active sites for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO. Fe/NG-750′s catalysts achieve the maximum FECO of ≈ 80% at −0.60 V versus RHE. The FE is also calculated at different pyrolyzing temperatures, and its value is decreased at higher temperatures due to the aggregation of the Fe atom. The FE is also estimated by varying the Fe precursor concentrations, and increasing the concentration of Fe decreases the FE value due to the formation of Fe3O4 and metallic Fe nanoparticles. The DFT calculation reveals that pyridinic Fe–N4 sites act as active centres and lower the free energy for CO2 adsorption and CO generation. The increasing N-doping also influences the CO2 conversion efficiency. In comparison to Fe–N4 sites, Fe–N5 sites are more active and selective towards CO2 conversions. For example, Zhang et al. synthesized Fe–N4 and Fe–N5 sites by pyrolysis of different molecular precursors and compared the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction [91]. In the synthesis process, the pyrolysis of hemin and melamine (H-M) mixture with iron precursor at higher temperature produce Fe-N4-C sites. The pyrolysis of hemin, melamine, and graphene (H-M–G) composite pyrolysis produces N-doped graphene, and the additional N of graphene axially combines with Fe-N4 sites to form Fe-N5-C materials (Fig. 14 a). The combined STEM-ADF and EELS measurements suggest that Fe atoms were atomically dispersed without aggregation on N doped graphene substrate. The XAS analysis confirms the presence of Fe-N4 and Fe-N5 sites in H-M and H-M–G catalysts, respectively. The synthesized Fe-N5-C catalysts exhibit higher activity and selectivity towards the formation of CO than Fe-N4-C catalysts. The catalysts' Fe-N5-C sites achieve the FECO of 97% at 0.46 V, which is quite higher than Fe-N4 sites (67%) (Fig. 14b). The Fe-N5 sites also achieve high current density for CO generation in comparison to Fe-N4 sites. Though the N and Fe content in Fe-N4 sites is high, it exhibits lower catalytic activity than Fe-N5 sites, which suggest additional axial N ligand plays a major role in enhancing the activity. Additionally, the unique electronic structure of Fe-N5 moieties enhanced conductivity, and high specific surface area of graphene are also responsible for enhancing the catalytic activity. The DFT calculation reveals that the additional axial N coordination of the Fe-N5 moieties further reduces the electron density around the 3d orbitals of metals and hence reduces the π back-donation of Fe–CO bond and that causes the weak adsorption and rapid desorption of CO (Fig. 14c). Not only isolated metal atoms but metal ions anchoring on nitrogen-doped carbon substrates also act as highly effective electrocatalysts for CO2 conversion. Gu et al. synthesized Fe+3 ion anchoring on N-doped carbon (Fe+3-N-C) by pyrolysis of Fe-doped ZIF-8 [28]. The AC-HAADF STEM image revealed that the atomic resolutions bright spot with atomic size are formed on the N-doped carbon subtract, and EDS mapping confirmed that the bright spots are Fe and Zn sites. The Fe K-edge EXAFS and XANES spectra support that the atomic dispersion of Fe+3 sites is coordinated to four pyrrolic-N atoms and containing Fe+3-N4 sites. The CO2 reduction activity Fe+3-N-C catalysts was tested in both H-cell and gas diffusion electrodes (GDE). In H-cell, the catalysts achieve the FE of more than 80% at the potential between –0.2 and –0.5 V versus RHE with the current density (j CO) of 20 mAcm−2 at 0.47 V versus RHE. In contrast, in GDE, the Fe+3-N-C catalysts achieve the FE of 90% with j CO of 94 mA cm−2 at –0.45 V versus RHE for the conversion of CO. The catalytic activity of Fe+3-N-C is higher than other benchmark catalysts. To understand the change in Fe+3-N-C sites during the electrochemical reaction, the author has studied the operand XAS measurements (Fig. 14d and e). The Fe K-edge spectra suggest that during the electrochemical CO2 reduction, Fe ions' oxidation state in Fe+3-N-C is +3 at potentials of −0.4 V vs. RHE. But when the higher negative potential was applied, Fe ions' oxidation state changed from Fe3+ to Fe2+ with changing local atomic structure and coordination number. The catalytic Fe+2-N-C sites were synthesized, and compare the electrocatalytic activity with Fe+3-N-C sites. The pyridinic-N ligands stabilize Fe+2 ions in Fe+2-N-C sites, whereas pyrrolic-N ligands stabilize Fe+3 ions Fe+3-N-C sites. The Fe+3-N-C sites exhibit higher catalytic activity than Fe+2-N-C sites due to the weaker binding of CO at Fe+3 sites. Cheng et al. developed the Fe-N-C sites decorated iron nitride (Fe x N) nanoparticles (FexN@Fe-N-C) for electrochemical CO2 conversion [195]. The catalysts achieve nearly 100% selectivity and ≈ 95% of FE at −0.53 V for CO conversion. The DFT studies revealed that iron nitride incorporated in the core of Fe, N shell lowering the free energy for the desorption of *CO. Huan et al. studied that the structural parameters of Fe-N-C materials dominate the selectivity toward the reduction of CO2 to CO [196]. They synthesized different wt% of Fe-SACs with the different conditions by the pyrolysis of ZIF-8, ferrous acetate, and phenanthroline. The higher the Fe content precursor forms the iron carbide (Fe3C2). The isolated Fe atom anchoring on the N-doped carbon matrix has square planer Fe-N4 sites. The Fe-N4 sites are recognized as the key catalytic active sites for high selectivity for the reductions CO2 to CO, and an increase in the ratio of Fe-N4 sites increases the selectivity. The catalysts achieve an FE of 91% at −0.6 V vs. RHE. Li et al. suggest that the catalytic Fe-N x centers have lower activity and selectivity than Fe-C and N-C-based centres to convert CO2 to CO [197]. 7.4 Cu single-atom catalysts (Cu-SACs) For electrochemical CO2RR, the Cu-based nanomaterials generate a series of conversion products such as CO, HCOOH, hydrocarbon, alcohol, etc. Cu-based nanomaterials' selectivity for forming a particular product in CO2RR is very low compared to other transition metals. So, increasing the reactivity and selectivity of Cu nanomaterials for electrochemical CO2 reduction remains a significant challenge. Different Cu-based nanostructure has been synthesized and studied for improving the selectivity for CO2 reduction [198–200]. Recently, isolated Cu atoms anchoring on different catalytic support such as nanocarbon, metal oxide, 2D-materials, etc., have been studied for electrochemical CO2RR [153,201–208]. In general, Cu-based SACs produced liquid fuels in CO2 reduction. The final product depends on the coordination environment around the isolated Cu atoms concentration of Cu loading, attachment of Cu with N-types, and nature of the anchoring sites. The different coordination environments around the isolated Cu atoms tune the metal loading produced different electrochemical CO2RR products. For example, Guan et al. tuned the loading of isolated Cu atoms or increased the Cu-N x sites anchoring on N-doped carbon by pyrolyzing the MOF precursors at different temperatures (Fig. 15 a and b) [189]. The pyrolysis at 800 °C (Cu-N-C-800) achieves the metal loading of 4.9 mol%. The higher concentrations of single-atomic Cu sites adjacent to Cu-N2 species are responsible for the formations of C–C bond, resulting in the formations of ethylene as a major reduction product with an FE of 24.8% at −1.4 V (Fig. 15c). When metal loading was dropped to 2.4 mol%, which can be achieved by pyrolyzing the MOF precursors at 900 °C (Cu-N-C-900), the isolated Cu-N4 species and isolated Cu-N2 neighboring to Cu-N4 are responsible for the formations of the C1 pathway. As a result, the CO2 reduction product is CH4 with an FE of 38.6% at −1.6 V (Fig. 15c). Apart from the metal loading, the types of N coordinated also affect the final product of CO2RR. The concentration of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N contents also control the CO2RR product. The varying concentration of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N contents was achieved by Zhao et al. by pyrolyzing the Cu-doped ZIF-8 in N2 (Cu-SA/NPC) and Ar (Cu-SA/NPCAr) atmosphere [153]. The XPS analysis revealed that Cu-SA/NPC is riched with higher pyrrolic N contents, and Cu-SA/NPCAr is riched with higher pyridinic N contents (Fig. 15d and e). The higher pyrrolic N contents Cu-SA/NPC catalysts convert CO2 into multiple products such as formic acid, acetic acid, methanol, ethanol, and acetone with acetone as a major product with FE of 36.7% at −0.36 V and a maximum production rate of 336.1 mg h−1 at −0.76 V (Fig. 15f and g). However, the higher pyridinic N containing Cu-SA/NPCAr catalysts have lower FE (13.2%) and production rate (248.8 μg h−1). This concludes the effect of N types on the CO2 reduction product. The DFT calculation suggests that pyrrolic-N4 sites provide the more favourable free energy for *COOH intermediate and C–C coupling formations compared to pyridinic-N4 sites. Thus, Cu–pyrrolic-N4 sites were considered as the major active sites for acetone formations. The substrate also plays a role in the production formations of CO2RR. For example, Yang et al. synthesized the isolated Cu atom anchoring of through-hole carbon nanofibers (Cu-SACs/TCNFs) by carbonizing Cu ions dispersed on ZIF-8 [179]. The synthesized Cu-SACs/TCNFs catalyst with Cu-N4 sites is directly used as cathode material for the electrochemical conversion of CO2. The catalysts Cu-SACs/TCNFs convert CO2 to the mixture of CH3OH and CO as a liquid and gas product. The catalysts exhibit the FE of 44% for CH3OH and 56% for CO at the potentials of −0.9 VRHE. The catalysts show the durability of up to 50 h at −0.9 VRHE for methanol formations. The higher activity of Cu-SACs/TCNFs is due to the synergetic effect of significant exposure of the Cu-N4 sites and the porous nature of TCNFs substrate. The DFT calculations reveal that the binding energy for *CO desorption in Cu-N4 sites is very high. As a result, the intermediate *CO is further reduced to CH3OH. Jiao et al.[208] anchor isolate Cu atoms on the matrix of g-C3N4 (Cu-C3N4). The support g-C3N4 materials uplift the d-band position toward the Fermi level by modifying the electronic structure of Cu-SACs that causes the increase in adsorption energy of the intermediate and CO2 activation. The catalysts Cu-C3N4 exhibit higher catalytic activity towards reduction CO2 to C2 products such as C2H6, C2H4, and C2H5OH. The catalysts exhibit high activity and selectivity for the formations of CH4 and CH3OH compared to Cu-NC. This concludes that Cu-SACs are the only transitional metals-based SACs to synthesize different hydrocarbons by reducing CO2. The Operando XAS measurement helps understand the catalytic transformation and active catalytic centre for CO2RR. For example, Karapinar et al. developed isolated Cu-N-C with Cu-N4 sites by two-step low energy ball milling and high-temperature pyrolysis method [180]. The catalysts Cu-N-C exhibit high selectivity for converting CO2 to ethanol (C2H5OH) with an FE of 55% at −1.55 VRHE. The operando XAS experiments suggest that the catalytic Cu-N4 sites are converted to small metallic Cu nanoparticles during electrolysis and active catalytic centers (Fig. 15h). Amazingly, after electrolysis, metallic Cu nanoparticles reestablished to the initial Cu-N4 form suggesting the strong interaction between Cu atoms and N anchoring sites. A similar observation is obtained by Xu et al. [205] . The operando XAS measurement suggests the reversible transformation of Cu-SACs to Cu clusters during the CO2 reduction process. In the reductive electrochemical environment, the Cu n (n = 3, 4) clusters act as active sites for the conversation of CO2 to CH3CH2OH with an FE of 91% (−0.7 V) (Fig. 15i). Dynamically after electrolysis, the Cu n clusters were oxidized to the initial Cu SACs. Also, no dissolved Cu was found in the electrolyte. The catalysts are also exhibiting long-term stability up to 16 h at −0.7 V. This concludes that single atoms' reversible conversion to clusters or nanoparticles acts as an active catalytic centre for CO2RR. The above results conclude that Ni, Co, and Fe-based SACs are high selectivity towards the two-electron reduction of CO2 to CO. In these SACs, M–N x (M = Ni, Co, Fe) species act as active sites, and the strong metal–ligand interaction and coordination environment of the isolated atoms play a major role in enhancing the activity and selectivity for the reductions of CO2 to CO. In comparison to M–N4 units, the vacancies and defect-rich M–N x species are highly active. They possess lower formation energy of *COOH intermediate and desorption of CO, which plays a major role in enhancing the activity of CO2RR. In the case of Cu-SACs, liquid fuels such as ethylene, methane, formic acid, acetic acid, methanol, ethanol, and acetone are the CO2 reduction product. The final product depends on the coordination environment, % of loading, anchoring sites' nature, and Cu's attachment with N-types and substrate. The different coordination environments around the isolated Cu atoms tune the metal loading produced different electrochemical CO2RR products. The Cu-N x species also act as an active centre for CO2RR. 7.5 Other single-atom catalysts The other metal elements such as Zn, Mn, Sn, Sb, and Bi SACs have also been extensively studied for electrochemical conversion of CO2. The Zn-based nanomaterials have high selectivity towards conversions of CO2 to CO [209,210]. Recently, isolated Zn atoms anchored on N-doped carbon (Zn-N-C) with Zn-N4 sites are extensively studied for electrochemical CO2RR with high selectivity towards CO conversion. Yang et al. achieved the faradic efficiency of 95% at a lower potential of −0.43 V for CO formations by synthesizing Zn single atoms supported on N-doped carbon matrix containing Zn-N4 sites [181]. The catalysts also achieve lower onset overpotentials (24 mV), high turnover frequency (9969 h−1), and long-term durability up to 75 h without degradations of FE. The DFT calculation reveals that the catalytic Zn-N4 sites lower the free energy of *COOH intermediate. Chen et al. synthesized Zn-SACs by pyrolysis method at a higher temperature from the mixture of graphene, melamine, and zinc acetate [182]. For electrocatalytic comparison, the catalysts are synthesized at different temperatures, i.e., 700 to 1000 °C, and the catalysts synthesized at 800 °C (Zn-N-G-800) exhibit higher catalytic activity. The catalysts Zn-N-G-800 achieved the FECO of 90.8% at a potential of −0.5 V and achieved the current density of 11.2 mA cm−2 at a lower potential of −0.8 V long-term durability for CO generations (Fig. 16 a). The theoretical calculation exposes that the Zn-N4 sites lower the energy of the formation of *COOH and desorption of *CO and enhance the Zn-N-G selectivity and reactivity catalysts. Other than the production of CO, Zn-based SACs form hydrocarbon-based products in electrochemical CO2 conversion. For example, by using Zn-SACs, Han et al. [188] successfully generates methane (CH4) by electrochemical CO2RR. The catalyst Zn-SACs achieve the high FE of 85%, a partial current density of −31.8 mA cm−2 at a potential of −1.8 V (SCE), and outstanding durability up to 35 h without dropping the current density or large fluctuation in FE. All the above result suggesting the superior performance for the conversion of CO2 to CH4 than that of dominant Cu-based catalysts. The DFT calculation reveal that single Zn atoms largely block CO generation and instead facilitate the production of CH4. The main group metal such as Sn, Sb, and Bi-based nanostructure have high selectivity for the formations of HCOOH by electrochemical CO2RR [211–214]. Whereas isolated Sn and Bi atoms form CO as a major product, and isolated Sn δ + and Sb atoms form the HCOOH as a major product. Recently, Zhao et al. synthesized isolated Sn atom anchoring on N-doped porous carbon nanofiber with metal loading of 1% and applied it for electrochemical CO2 reduction [185]. The catalyst achieved a high FECO of 91% at −0.6 V with j CO of 1.75 mA cm−2, which is quite higher than the bare N-doped porous carbon nanofiber. The high selectivity of CO conversion is due to the presence of Sn-N sites. The author also synthesized Sn nanoparticles dispersed on the N-doped carbon nanofibers and studied the electrochemical CO2 reduction. Sn NPs and pyridinic nitrogen's strong interactions in catalysts favor the formations of HCOOH with an FE of 62% at the overpotential of 690 mV. This further confirmed that Sn-SACs have high selectivity towards CO conversion. Whereas isolated Sn δ + atom anchored on N-doped graphene exhibits high selectivity towards formations of formate [145]. The Sn atom is coordinated to two nitrogen and two carbon atoms in N-doped graphene. Sn atoms' electron density shifted towards graphene. As a result, the positive charge is highly delocalized, resulting in formations of Sn δ + centers (Fig. 16b). The catalysts achieve the high FEHCOOH of 74.3% at −1.6 VSEC with a high TOF of 11930 h−1 (−1.8 V) (Fig. 16c). The catalysts exhibit long-term durability up to 200 h without any change in FEHCOOH (Fig. 16d). The in situ FTIR analysis suggests that Sn δ + centers stabilize CO2 −* and HCOO−* (Fig. 16e). The activation and protonation processes were steady with free energy calculations. To enhance the selectivity of CO2RR towards the formations of HCOOH, Jiang et al. synthesized Sb-SACs rich in Sb δ +-N4 anchoring sites on ultrathin N-doped graphene-like carbon (Sb-SAs/NC) substrate [187]. The Sb-SAs/NC catalysts exhibit a higher FEHCOOH of 94% at −0.8 V, higher than other reported catalysts. The in situ XAS measurement suggests that change in Sb-N4 bond length and oxidation state of Sb atom during the reductions and Sb δ +-N4 anchoring sites act as active sites for CO2RR (Fig. 16 f and g). The SCN− ion poison experiment also confirms this result. In comparison to Sn and Sb, Bi-SACs are more selective towards the formations of CO. For example, Zhang et al. synthesized Bi single atoms are anchoring on N-doped carbon (Bi-SAs/NC) by pyrolysis of Bi-MOFs [186]. Ammonia plays a major role in the atomization of Bi. The Bi-SAs/NC is rich with Bi–N4 anchoring sites with the valencies state of Bi atoms is between 0 and 3+ (Bi δ +, 0 < δ < 3). The Bi-SAs/NC achieves the maximum FE CO of 97% at −0.5 V, which is relatively higher than Bi clusters (Bi Cs/NC) and Bi nanoparticles (Bi NPs/NC) (Fig. 16h). The DFT calculations suggest that the lower Gibbs free energy barrier for *COOH formation suggests the low onset potential and enhanced CO2RR activity (Fig. 16i). 8 Dual-atom catalysts (DACs) Compared to aforesaid M–N4 sites, incorporation of another metal site called dual-atom sites catalysts (DASCs) modulates the active center's electronic and geometric structure, facilitates the electron transfer between the metal centre, and provides more opportunities for different electrocatalytic applications [215–218]. Currently, dual-atom sites catalysts (DASCs) have attracted widespread attention among researchers, and it is an extension of isolated SACs. DASCs have many advantages over SACs such as higher percentage of metal loading, unique electronic structures, strong interaction, more number of unsaturated co-ordinations complex, higher homogeneous catalytic active sites, lowering the reaction energy barrier and that exhibiting the great potential to improve catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability in a broad variety of applications [215]. Based on the position of the atoms, DASCs are classified into isolated and binuclear dual-atom sites catalysts. In isolated DASCs, central atoms are coordinated to surrounding heteroatoms (M–N4 units) without forming metal–metal bonds, and the proposed structure is M1M2-N8-C (Fig. 17 a). In binuclear DASCs, two central atoms are coordinated with each other along with the surrounding heteroatoms, and the proposed structure is M1M2-N6-C (Fig. 17b) [217]. For electrochemical CO2RR, the isolated metal centre has limitations in its efficiency, stability, and deep reduction product. For example, Ni-N x has suffered higher overpotentials due to weak adsorption energy of *COOH intermediate. Similarly, Fe-N x and Co-N x sites have lower reactivity and lower current density due to the strong desorption energy of *CO. Thus, the adsorption energy of *COOH and *CO intermediate on metal sites (M–N x ) are the critical factor for reactivity and selectivity for CO conversion. The DASCs overcome this issue by modifying the electronic structure and coordination environment, lowering the reaction energy barrier, and leading to the formation of C2 products. The different DASCs such as NiFe, CuFe, ZnCo, FeFe, NiCo have been reported for electrochemical CO2RR [123,219–222]. The DFT calculation suggests that DASCs are active for different CO2RR products such as CO, CH3CH2OH, HCOOH, CH4 [216]. For example, Ouyang et al. reported that the linear relationship could be broken by forming DASCs to achieve efficient CO2RR via First-principles calculations [219]. Different kinds of DASCs such as CuMn, CuCr, MnCr, and FeCr are anchoring in C2N substrate. The Free energy diagram suggests that CuCr/C2N and CuMn/C2N efficiently reduced the CO2 to CH4 with a lower overpotential of −0.37 and −0.32 V, respectively. The utilizations of difference in carbophilicity and oxophilicity of metal atoms to form oxophilic and carbophilic dual active sites are responsible for higher activity towards CO2RR. Experimentally also, different DASCs have been demonstrated for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO [123,220,221]. For example, Ren et al. recently synthesized the isolated diatomic metal-nitrogen site (Ni-Fe-N-C) by the pyrolysis of Zn/Ni/Fe-ZIF-8 [123]. For catalytic comparison, individual metal-nitrogen sites are synthesized by pyrolysis of corresponding metal ions doped ZIF-8. The incorporated diatomic Ni-Fe-N-C sites exhibit higher activity and selective CO conversion. The Ni-Fe-N-C sites achieve the FECO of more than 90% at a wide potential range (−0.5 to −0.9 V) and show a maximum of 98% at −0.7 V, a relatively higher individual Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C sites (Fig. 17c). The theoretical calculation revealed the diatomic nitrogen sites endure a structural change that helps to CO-adsorbed moiety upon CO2 uptake and lower the free energy of the intermediate *COOH and CO desorption (Fig. 17d). This is an extraordinary electrocatalyst for improving CO conversion. Similarly, for improving CO selectivity, Lin et al. developed diatomic Fe-N-C sites anchoring on cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc@Fe-N-C) [222]. The catalysts achieve the FECO of 90% at the potential range from 0.18 to 0.71 V, which is much higher than individual Fe-N-C and CoPc@Zn-N-C sites. CoPc and Fe-N-C sites' synergistic interaction improves the current density, % of FECO, and durability. The DFT calculation suggests that CoPc sites promoted the desorption of CO and suppressed the HER at Fe-N sites. 9 Challenges and opportunities For a sustainable and clean environment, the development of highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts is of great attention. The electrochemical conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuels is the best method to reduce atmospheric CO2 and maintain carbon cycles. Last couple of decades, both noble and transition metal-based nanostructures have been synthesized and optimized for electrochemical CO2RR. The low cost and earth-abundant resources of transition metals have made them the preferential choice for CO2RR catalysis. Different molecular strategies developed to increase the efficiency of the CO2RR catalysis and decrease particle size or synthesize the SACs is an effective catalyst design strategy that has led to substantially enhanced catalytic performance towards CO2RR. The plummeting of particle size of metal catalyst to isolate a single atom is the best way to maximize atomic efficiency and enhance intrinsic catalytic activity. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) supported on different matrices have high electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, and stability towards different electrochemical reactions. The high efficiency and selectivity of SACs towards CO2RR are due to the advantages of both homogeneous, heterogeneous systems. SACs have a quantum size effect, high atom utilization efficiency, a unique coordination environment, highly active edge sites, and strong interaction with support catalysts, making the catalysts highly active and selective towards CO2RR [223–225]. The efficiency and selectivity of SACs towards CO2RR depend on the types of metal ions, nature of coordination environment, and nature of support catalysts. For M–N–C (M = Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Zn, etc.) based SACs, the active sites' metal-nitrogen coordination environment (M–N x ) affects the catalytic activity selectivity towards CO2RR [224,226]. Recently, great research efforts and excitement have been devoted to developing different SACs for CO2RR; still, significant challenges and opportunities are prevailing for fundamental and applied research perspectives. From the beginning, the accumulation of isolated atoms is a vital problem for the synthesis of SACs. Decreasing the size of the material increase the surface energy, and higher surface energy causes the aggregation of isolated single atoms to nanoparticles or nanoclusters. Thus, to avoid the aggregation of single atoms, the proper selections of the catalytic support and concentration of metal ions precursor play a key role. In the support catalysts, the nature of the anchoring sites and strong interactions could stabilize the isolated single atoms, and the anchoring sites would be created by doing defect engineering in the support catalysts. The nature of the coordination atoms plays a key role in achieving highly stable and structural uniformity SACs and avoiding the formation of nanoparticles or nanoclusters. Different support catalysts such as metals oxide, sulphide, layer double hydroxide (LDH), Mxene, and different nanocarbon such as graphene, g-C3N4, and heteroatom doped carbon have been used to stabilize the different SACs. The development of SACs with high metals loading and uniform atomic dispersion of isolated atoms on the support catalysts has remained a great challenge in the different synthesis processes. The high metal loading generally depends on the surface area, uniform dispersions of metal ions precursor, number of anchoring sites, and strong interaction of coordination sites and metal ions. High energy inputs are required in both top-down and bottom-up synthesis processes due to the bond breaking and making process. That causes the accumulations of the isolated atom. As a result, it decreases the amount of metal loading. Thus, the metal loading in most of the SACs is below 5%. The catalytic activity and selectivity of SACs depend on the number of exposed surface atoms, and the higher are the metal loading more is the exposed surface atoms. Thus, the catalytic activity and selectivity of SACs are higher in comparison to NPs or NCs. To increase metal loading in the SACs, the defect engineering in support catalysts could be explored to create new anchoring sites and stabilize a higher percentage of metal loadings. Recently, Li et al. reported copper SAC with high metal loading of 20.9 wt% [227]. Yet, more exertions are still essential, either modifying the existing synthesis process or developing a new process to minimize the accumulation of a single atom to enhance the metal loading. Most of TM-SACs have focused on nitrogen heteroatoms as anchoring sites with isolated MN x moieties. The other heteroatom dopants, such as B, S, P, O, Se, etc., are less explored as anchoring sites for the isolated metal atom or as dopants in the support catalysts. The assimilation of these heteroatoms could deliver new paths to modify the coordinate atom's electronic structure and may increase the catalytic activity of the SACs. Incorporating two or more different dopants anchoring on the same or different single atoms could provide another path for tuning the intrinsic activity of the SACs. Moreover, the electrocatalytic activity of SACs depends on the coordination environment or active sites and depends on the physicochemical properties such as surface area, porosity, and electrical conductivity of the support matrix and are sensitive to the synthesis process. Thus, it remains a significant challenge to understand the fundamental relationship between local atomic structures and electrocatalytic performance. The TM-SACs have excellent electrocatalytic activity and selectivity towards the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO; however, significantly lower activity and small electrolysis current density of less than 10 mA cm−2 towards other hydrocarbon and fuel generations. Only Cu-SACs directly convert the CO2 to hydrocarbon and fuels. Thus, developing TM-SACs that can directly convert CO2 to hydrocarbon and fuels with high selectivity. This can be achieved by optimizing the catalytic support matrix, different anchoring dopants, different coordination environments, and scientific understanding. According to DFT calculations, instead of TM-SACs, noble metal (Pt, Pd, Ru, Rh, Ir, etc.) NM-SACs and alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca, Ba, Sr) AM-SACs can cause electrochemical reduction of CO2. However, experimentally these SACs are still not reported now. So, synthesizing NM-SACs and AM- SACs and studying the electrochemical reduction of CO2 gives another opportunity and fundamental challenge to materials researchers. In 2014, he joined Dr. Bikash Kumar Jena groups in the Department of Materials Chemistry, CSIR-Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology, Bhubaneswar, India, for a Ph.D. program. His research focuses on developing 2D, non-2D metal nanostructures, Quantum Dots, and composite with MXene and different nanocarbon materials and studied their electrochemical properties such as HER, OER Supercapacitor, and Sensing applications. He is currently working on different transition metal-based single atoms catalysis (TM-SACs) towards the ORR, NRR, and CO2RR applications. Suddhasatwa Basu (FNASc, FNAE, FRSC, FICS) is a Professor of Chemical Engineering Department Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, India, and Director of CSIR-Institute of Minerals and Materials Technology, Bhubaneswar, India. He is a Fellow of the National Academy of Science of India and Indian Chemical Society, Indian National Academy of Engineering, Royal Society of Chemistry. He received his Ph.D. degree in 1993 from the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India. His research interests focus on SOFC, PEMFC, CO2 to chemical fuel by electrochemical and photoelectrochemical reduction cell, Non-PGM ORR and OER catalysts, Microfluidics - micro plant, lab on a chip, Glucose fuel cell - the power source for body implants, Direct hydrocarbon SOFC- anode development - Cu-Ceria, Sr-titanates, Ni-YDC, Electrolyte (GDC, LDC, SDC and carbonates) for low temp solid oxide fuel cell. Prof. Basu is an Associate Editor of Wiley Journal WIRES: Energy & Environment. He has published more than 220 international journals (>5200 citations, H index:38) and 4786 conference papers and filed more than 5 patents. coredata.dc:description: The continuous increase of global atmospheric CO2 concentrations brutally damages our environment. A series of methods have been developed to convert CO2 to valuable fuels and value-added chemicals to maintain the equilibrium of carbon cycles. The electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is one of the promising methods to produce fuels and chemicals, and it could offer sustainable paths to decrease carbon intensity and support renewable energy. Thus, significant research efforts and highly efficient catalysts are essential for converting CO2 into other valuable chemicals and fuels. Transition metal-based single atoms catalysts (TM-SACs) have recently received much attention and offer outstanding electrochemical applications with high activity and selectivity opportunities. By taking advantage of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, TM-SACs are the new rising star for electrochemical conversion of CO2 to the value-added product with high selectivity. In recent years, enormous research effort has been made to synthesize different TM-SACs with different M–N x sites and study the electrochemical conversion of CO2 to CO. This review has discussed the development and characterization of different TM-SACs with various catalytic sites, fundamental understanding of the electrochemical process in CO2RR, intrinsic catalytic activity, and molecular strategics of SACs responsible for CO2RR. Furthermore, we extensively review previous studies on 1st-row transition metals TM-SACs (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Zn, Sn) and dual-atom catalysts (DACs) utilized for electrochemical CO2 conversions and highlight the opportunities and challenges.
